7.1 At that time, the Buddha told ÅšÄriputra:ğŸ”½What is the perfection of morality of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
For the sake of supreme perfect enlightenment,
relying on this, they diligently practice the bodhisattva path.
ÅšÄriputra!
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, there are three kinds of wonderful practices.
What are the three?
First, the wonderful practice of the body, second, the wonderful practice of speech, and third, the wonderful practice of the mind.
ÅšÄriputra, what are called the wonderful practice of the body, the wonderful practice of speech, and the wonderful practice of the mind?
ÅšÄriputra!

It is said that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are far removed from killing, far removed from taking what is not given, and far removed from sexual misconduct, which is called the wonderful practice of the body.
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are far removed from false speech, far removed from divisive speech, far removed from harsh speech, and far removed from frivolous speech. This is called the excellent practice of speech.
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have no greed, anger, or wrong views at all. This is called the excellent practice of the mind.
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are endowed with these three excellent practices, this is called the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, they think like this:
'What is the excellent practice of body, speech, and mind?'
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'If the body does not commit the acts of killing, stealing, or sexual misconduct, this is called the excellent practice of the body.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'If one does not engage in false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, or frivolous speech, this is called good verbal action.'
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva thinks like this:
'If the mind does not engage in covetousness, ill-will, or wrong views, this is called good mental action.'
Because of possessing such correct thought, this is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practicing the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Thus, when the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva practices the perfection of morality, he thinks like this:
'If an action is not created by body, speech, or mind, can this action be established?'

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva observes in this way: 'If an action is not created by body, speech, or mind, this action cannot be established, whether it is blue, yellow, red, white, crimson, or the color of crystal.'
This karma is not cognizable by the eye, not cognizable by the ear, nose, tongue, body, or mind.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
Because this karma is not that which gives rise to, that which is given rise to, or that which gives rise to itself, it cannot be grasped, and there is none at all that can cognize this karma.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas understand that the nature of this morality cannot be made, and if it cannot be made, then it cannot be established. If it cannot be established, then we should not become attached to it.

In this way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, by the power of understanding and insight, do not see good conduct or morality, nor do they see one who possesses morality, nor do they see where morality is directed.
Having contemplated in this way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas ultimately do not give rise to the false view of a real self.
Why is it so?
ÅšÄriputra!
Because of the view of a real self, one may have contemplation, thinking this is morality and this is immorality.

Having contemplated in this way, with regard to guarding and rules, whether in action or realm, they are all fully aware and practice correctly. Because of practicing correctly, they are called those who uphold precepts.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not grasp at self and do not grasp at others while practicing. They do not violate the precepts and do not grasp at the precepts while practicing.
If one grasps at self, one grasps at the precepts. If one is not attached to self, one does not grasp at the precepts.
If one knows that the precepts are unobtainable, then one does not violate the precepts.
If one does not violate the precepts, then one is not called one who violates the precepts, and one is also not called one who grasps at the precepts.
ÅšÄriputra!
For what reason does one not grasp at these precepts?
It is because one knows the characteristics of all dharmas as they are.
If it is by the characteristics of others, then there is no self. If self is nonexistent, what is there to grasp at?
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
If one's body, speech, and mind are pure, and one always cultivates purity in action,
And always abides in the pure precepts, this is called a bodhisattva who is endowed with precepts.
The wise and sagacious bodhisattvas are able to well protect and uphold the ten paths of action,
Not by means of body, speech, or mind. Such is the explanation of precepts by the wise.
If it is neither created nor produced, neither grasped nor formless, nor even manifest,
Because of having no form and being manifest, it has never been possible to establish it.
Precepts are unconditioned and also uncreated, not seen by the eyes nor heard by the ears,
Not the nose, not the tongue, nor also the body, and not able to be cognized by the mind.
If it is not cognized by the six sense faculties, then there is no one who can establish it,
Thus observing the purity of precepts, never relying on or abiding in the precepts.
Not relying on upholding precepts to give rise to arrogance, not considering the thought of self to protect precepts,
Well protecting precepts without the thought of precepts, fully endowed with precepts and the practice of awakening.
Falsely existing views of self have already been eliminated, views and the one who sees have never existed,
There is no one who can see and no such place, not observing those who uphold precepts or violate precepts.
Well entering the principle of being without protection, endowed with inconceivable deportment,
Skillfully and correctly able to guard and protect, apart from this there is no one with fully endowed precepts.
One without the thought of self has no precepts, one who can rely on precepts without depending on anything,
I say this is ultimate, always fearless, not grasping at the body as self and precepts.ğŸ”½One who speaks of no self does not grasp at precepts, one who speaks of no self has no basis for precepts,
One who speaks of no self does not hope for precepts, one who speaks of no self has no mind for precepts.
Not reviling precepts, not grasping at precepts, not conceiving of self,
Without reliance on self or the notion of precepts, practicing the profound wisdom and the conduct of enlightenment.
Such precepts are fearless, this person always does not violate precepts,
If one is able not to grasp at the existence of dharmas, such precepts are praised by the sages.
If foolish people abide in the view of self, conceiving of self as possessing precepts and able to uphold precepts,
Having received and guarded the fruits of precepts, they will always be bound to the three evil destinies.
If there are those who have completely severed the view of self, they have neither self nor what belongs to self,
This is truly upholding precepts without views, and there is no more fear of falling into evil destinies.
If one is able to know the practice of precepts in this way, there is no one who can see the violation of precepts,
Not even observing self and the three realms of existence, let alone seeing the upholding of precepts and the violation of precepts.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

In this way, when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the pure precepts of bodhisattva conduct while practicing the perfection of morality, they possess ten kinds of extremely grave and profound thoughts.
What are the ten?

First, they give rise to a profound mind of faith and reverence for all practices; second, they give rise to a profound mind of diligence and exertion; third, they ardently delight in the true Dharma of the buddhas; fourth, they extensively and respectfully engage in all karmic activities; fifth, they deeply harbor faith and reverence for all karmic retributions; sixth, they deeply give rise to a mind of respect for all sages; seventh, they serve with purity the venerable upÄdhyÄyas and ÄcÄryas; eighth, they make offerings to the sages; ninth, they diligently seek the true Dharma; tenth, when seeking enlightenment, they do not care about their own lives.
ÅšÄriputra!ğŸ”½The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice morality in this way have these ten profound mental states.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the profound mind and cultivate wholesome dharmas.
What are called the various good dharmas?
They are called the three kinds of wonderful practices:
Wonderful practice of body, wonderful practice of speech, and wonderful practice of mind.
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in these three kinds of wonderful practices, they will diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattvas.
Why is this so?
Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas rely on this Dharma door to be able to reach supreme, perfect enlightenment.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
By means of the body, one gives rise to the good karma praised by the Buddha,ğŸ”½In order to hear the Dharma, one makes offerings to the sages and saints.
Toward the Dharma and the sages, one gives rise to intense respect,
In order to benefit all beings, one has a compassionate mind and is not jealous.ğŸ”½One should speak the words of the wise, not speak unpleasant words,
The spoken words are of joyful appearance, and one's speech is not coarse or vulgar.
The mind always abides in goodness, never delighting in evil,
Always contemplating the nature of dharmas, respectfully abiding with a compassionate mind.
With a respectful mind, listen to the Dharma in the TathÄgata's holy teachings,
Having respected the Dharma, quickly realize great enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, abide in these ten supreme principles. In order to diligently seek the Dharma of the Bodhisattva Canon, they diligently add respect and serve and make offerings to all teachers and elders, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, should be equipped with these ten kinds of thoughts.
What are the ten?
ÅšÄriputra!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe this sick body, the poisonous snakes of the various elements constantly harming each other, with much suffering and many faults, with many illnesses such as epilepsy, boils, sores, psoriasis, leprosy, wind, heat, and phlegm.
Moreover, this body is like an illness, like a wound, like being pierced by an arrow, like a rushing stream, like a butcher, shaking and moving without rest, quickly arising and quickly ceasing.
Moreover, they observe that this body is false, weak, old, decaying, and easily destroyed, temporarily staying still, difficult to love and enjoy, like a charnel ground.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought like this:
Although this sick body of mine has experienced this suffering, I have never encountered such a field of blessings.

I now get to encounter it, and moreover, I have well received such a body. I should rely on the various fields of blessings to nurture the wisdom-life, abandon the unsolid body and obtain the solid body.

In order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the Great Bodhisattva Canon, they serve and make offerings to the venerable teachers, the virtuous UpÄdhyÄyas and Ä€cÄryas, and even offer them water containers.
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the first thought of enlightenment of the Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
The violent poisonous snakes in the realms mutually rely on each other,
If any one of them becomes agitated, it will give rise to great calamity.ğŸ”½Namely, the eyes, ears, nose,
Tongue, teeth, and internal organs,
Such afflictions and troubles all arise from the body.
Boils, abscesses, epilepsy,
And various other illnesses all arise from the body.
This body is like an illness, like a boil, like an arrow stuck in the body,
Such a poisonous and harmful body, quickly perishes and only temporarily exists,
Like going to that cemetery, all are impermanent characteristics,
The shaking and decaying body, various illnesses quickly arise and perish.
I should cultivate the virtuous karma that is the cause of the Buddha's body,
With that decaying and perishable body, which is impermanent due to old age,
Transform it into the Buddha's body and the inconceivable Dharma body.
With such decay and perishability, the body that flows with impurities everywhere,
One should realize such a body that is free from impurities and defilements.
If a person is afraid of cold and heat, blocking and firmly guarding against them,
In the end, they will be harmed by the suffering of old age, sickness, and death, all boiling together.
If a person can endure cold and heat, pervading the entire body,
Adorning the deeds of a great man, quickly accomplishing the unsurpassed body.
I should diligently make offerings to the one respected by the world,
With this insubstantial body, I shall trade for that which is substantial.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, after giving rise to such foremost thoughts, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, they will serve the Dharma teacher even more respectfully and increase their offerings, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, give rise to this thought:
'The body is of an insubstantial nature, not solid or firm, and must be covered, washed, and massaged, yet in the end it will return to breaking apart, dispersing, and grinding to dust.'
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a potter making earthenware vessels, whether large or small, they will in the end break apart.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
The body is insubstantial and will in the end break apart, like those earthenware vessels.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
It is like the branches of a tree, which depend on the flowers, leaves, and fruits, and eventually fall down.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
The body is not solid and must fall down, its power not lasting long, like a ripe fruit and so forth.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
It is like the dew on the tip of a blade of grass, which when illuminated by the sun's light will certainly not remain.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
The body is not solid, like a drop of dew, and will not remain for long.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
It is like the great ocean and all the rivers, which have masses of foam, all of which are not solid, their nature weak and unable to be touched.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
This body is not solid, like a mass of foam, and its fundamental nature is weak in the same way.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
It is like when the heavens rain heavily, and the floating bubbles rise and fall slowly.
In this way, ÅšÄriputra!
The body is not solid, like bubbles on water, and its nature is light and thin in the same way.
ÅšÄriputra!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas deeply contemplate the body and, having seen these things, further think like this:
'I have for a long time experienced such an insubstantial body, and have never encountered such a field of merit.

Now that I have encountered it, and have further well experienced such a body, I should rely on the various fields of merit to nurture the wisdom-life, and with this insubstantial body trade for a substantial body, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon. Therefore, I will serve and make offerings to the Dharma teacher, and even offer vessels for storing water.'
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the second thought aroused by the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Just as the various potters of the world, using clay to make earthenware,
All will eventually break and perish, so is the life of sentient beings.
It is like the branches of a tree, on which are leaves, flowers, and fruits,
All return to the Dharma of falling, human life is also like this.
Like dew on the tip of grass, illuminated by the sun,
In a moment, not staying for a moment, human life is also like this.
Like the foam gathering in the river and sea, its nature is originally weak,
This unfirm body, floating and empty, is also like this.
Like when the heavens rain heavily, producing water bubbles floating,
In an instant, quickly disappearing, the unfirm body is also like this.
The unfirm giving rise to the thought of firmness, in the thought of firmness, unfirm,
The practice of mistaken discrimination, unable to realize the firm reality.
In firmness, giving rise to the wisdom of firmness, the unfirm knowing the unfirm,
The practice of correct discrimination, able to realize the firm reality.
In order to cultivate the thought of firm reality, slightly giving a water vessel,
Therefore, with this unfirm body, trading for that firm reality.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, after giving rise to this second thought, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, they will serve the Dharma teacher even more respectfully and increase their offerings, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, give rise to this thought:

'For a long time I have been far from good friends, and have been held by evil friends. My nature is lazy and I do not cultivate diligence. I am inferior, foolish, and have many wrong views. I falsely give rise to such deluded and unwholesome thoughts: there is no giving, no love, no sacrifice, no good deeds, and no evil deeds. There is no increase in the fruits of karma.'
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'I was confused by greed and desire, wandering for a long time, creating various evil and unwholesome karma.

By the power of this unwholesome evil karma, I have attained a defiled and evil self-nature as retribution, born in the realm of hungry ghosts lacking the necessities of life, without any supreme field of blessings.

Moreover, I was once born in the realm of hungry ghosts, always eating charcoal and fire for countless years, and for many hundreds of thousands of years I did not hear the name of water, let alone touch it with my body.'
He also thought like this:

'Now I have encountered such a supreme field of blessings, and I have attained a good body with abundant necessities. I should rely on the fields of blessings to extensively cultivate wholesome karma, disregarding my body and life to serve my teachers and preceptors. In order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, I will respectfully serve and make offerings to the Dharma teachers, up to offering them even a vessel for holding water.'
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the third thought of enlightenment of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
Thus, the good and virtuous friend should always be closely attended and respectfully served,
Because by becoming such a nature, one should frequently draw near.
Being held by bad friends, one is far removed from wise and good friends,
Lazy and contemptuous of diligence, stingy, jealous, and full of flattery,
Without giving and other wrong views, but not denying everything.
I have been born in the realm of hungry ghosts, receiving an evil and coarse form,
In the long night of birth and death, in the great darkness of fear,
Tormented by hunger and thirst all over, suffering many hardships,
For many hundreds of thousands of years, I have never heard the name of water,
Not seeing a pure field of blessings, not being able to avoid this difficulty.
I now experience this difficult-to-obtain world,
And again, I respectfully serve the wise and virtuous, attaining the perfection of being free from difficulties,
And also avoiding evil friends, I encounter virtuous and good friends,
Vowing not to care for my body and life, I shall attain enlightenment.
With a pure and wholesome mind, I respectfully serve the venerable teachers,
And I shall also make offerings to the buddhas, in order to attain enlightenment.
ÅšÄriputra!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, after giving rise to this third thought, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, they will serve the Dharma teacher even more respectfully and make offerings, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, they give rise to this thought:

'For a long time I have been far from good friends, held by evil friends, lazy and indolent, with inferior diligence, ignorant and foolish. Due to such views and such acceptance, when sentient beings experience various sufferings and cry out in grief and lamentation, I would further strike them with my body and hands, causing various harms and afflictions.
Because of these causes and conditions, I then gave rise to such immeasurable evil views, saying there are no evil actions and no retribution for evil actions.

Moreover, because of being covered by anger, I created various evil and unwholesome actions. Due to the retribution of these actions, I obtained a filthy and evil body and was born among animals, lacking the necessities of life and without any supreme field of blessings.'
The Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva thinks like this:
'In those realms, I may become a camel, ox, donkey, and so forth, eating grass, being beaten with sticks, scolded, frightened, and forced to carry heavy loads against my will.'
He further thinks like this:
'Although I have experienced these sufferings in the past, I have never encountered such a field of merit.

I have now encountered it, and moreover, I have well attained such a body. I shall rely on the fields of merit, disregarding my life, and with this impermanent body, trade for a permanent body. I shall serve my teachers and elders, in order to diligently seek the sublime Dharma door of the great bodhisattvas. For the sake of the Dharma teacher, I shall make offerings and serve, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.'
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the fourth resolve of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
At that time the World-Honored One, wanting to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
For a long time I did not know how to ascend the holy path,
Falling into the states of camels, oxen, and donkeys, I suffered much hardship.
Now that I have attained a human body, I shall cultivate virtuous and wholesome deeds,
By this I shall realize enlightenment, this is the characteristic of being wise.
I should arouse respect and establish the Buddhadharma,
And serve the Dharma teachers in order to attain enlightenment.
In the past, inconceivable eons ago, I cycled through the wheel of birth and death,
Coming and going without benefit, without a field of merit to sustain my life.
Far from good spiritual friends, I always associated with bad companions,
Following their teachings, I often fell into various evil states.
I once, as an animal, was bound, driven, beaten, and scolded,
Because of these evil karmic acts, I experienced the unpleasant fruits of suffering.
Thus I fell into an evil state, becoming a camel, ox, or donkey,
Bearing heavy burdens and still being beaten, because I did not associate with good friends.
I have now attained the difficult-to-obtain human body and good friends,
Having been born in a good place, I have also encountered no difficulties,
Like a turtle dwelling in the ocean for a long time, joyfully encountering the hole in a floating log,
Guarding well body and speech, with vigorous and powerful mind,
Without flattery, serving good friends, nurturing the body of wisdom.
If there is respect for the teacher who arouses the mind of wisdom in me,
Able to proclaim the supreme and wonderful, the great teacher of the path to enlightenment,
Making offerings to the Honored One of the two-footed, with various ointments, powders,
And various garments, flower garlands, I shall respectfully receive and offer.
The buddhas of the present in the ten directions, with the supreme truth always revealed,
The boundless golden-colored sun, I shall practice and make offerings.
Traveling to all buddha-lands, making extensive offerings to the Tamer,
In order to purify the path to enlightenment, I shall ascend the great enlightenment seat.
ÅšÄriputra!

When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice the perfection of morality, after giving rise to these fourth kinds of thoughts, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, they redouble their service and offerings to the Dharma teacher, up to giving even a vessel for holding water.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, give rise to thoughts such as this:

'I have for a long time in the past been far removed from good friends, constrained by evil friends, lazy and indolent with inferior diligence, lacking wisdom and foolish, giving rise to evil views, thus believing and enduring, with such desires, falsely thinking:

If one takes the flesh of all sentient beings and all living beings, cooks it in a single cauldron, or takes their bodies and chops them up together, although one does this it is not called non-merit.
They also give rise to evil views, thinking that this does not lead to evil, that this does not lead to the arising of evil.
Because of false views, they give to all beings on this shore of the great ocean, satisfying all their generosity, and although they do this, it is not considered a non-offense.
Falsely giving rise to different calculations, they think that this does not lead to blessings, that this does not lead to the arising of blessings.

Because of false views, they kill all beings on the other shore of the great ocean, and also do not lead to the incurring of evil because of this, and do not lead to the arising of evil because of this.'
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva thinks like this:

'In the past, I did this, but was unable to understand what is an offense and what is not an offense, what is a blessing and what is not a blessing. Adhering to evil views, obscured by foolishness, I created much unwholesome and grave evil karma.

Due to this karmic retribution, they will receive a body in the lower, inferior, filthy, and evil hells, where in the hells they will either eat iron pellets or be sawed apart, experiencing various kinds of hard and bitter suffering, pure suffering without interruption continuing on and on, for many hundreds of thousands of years, not even hearing the sound of happiness, let alone physically touching it.
At that time the Bodhisattva further thought like this:
'Although I experienced this suffering in the past, I never encountered such a field of merit.

I now get to encounter it, and moreover have well received such a body. I should rely on the fields of merit to nurture the wisdom-life, trading this impermanent body for a permanent body, not caring for body or life in serving the teachers, in order to diligently seek the wondrous Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, and therefore serve and make offerings to the Dharma teachers, even offering them vessels for storing water.'
ÅšÄriputra!
This is called the fifth thought of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:
I have been close to evil friends, deceived by evil thoughts,
Relying on various evil views, in vain giving rise to evil karma.
From this shore of the great ocean, all the beings that dwell,
Giving them food and drink to fill them, is said not to bring about the blessings of rebirth;
From the other shore of the great ocean, all the beings that dwell,
I have killed them all, it is said not to bring about evil karma.
Such evil views, often practiced and always befriended,
Fall into the most painful hell, where the body and head are crushed.
In the past, in the three evil destinies, in vain exhausting hundreds of thousands of bodies,
I have never seen the buddhas, the leaders of the world.
The name of the world's good friend, its sound is still difficult to hear,
I am fortunate among humans, I should cultivate virtuous and good karma.
It is extremely difficult to obtain a human body, and having obtained it, a long life is difficult;
It is difficult to encounter the correct Dharma, and it is difficult for Buddhas to appear in the world.
I have already obtained a human body, and have this fragile life;
I have encountered the Buddha appearing in the world, and am included in the TathÄgata's correct teachings.
I will no longer engage in evil actions of body, speech, and mind;
Do not let me in the future experience unloved bitter fruits.
With my pure mind, I will cultivate pure actions;
Through body, speech, and mind, I will perform difficult practices in the world.
I will never go against the teachings approved by the teacher and the assembly;
Moreover, I will make offerings, for the sake of Buddhahood.
Because I am not deceitful or deceptive, and have no false mind,
I will open up and cultivate the straight path, for the path to Buddhahood.
The fearless great bodhisattva has already given rise to such a mind;
Offering water containers, wisdom and skillful means are complete.
ÅšÄriputra!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, having given rise to this fifth thought, in order to diligently seek the subtle Dharma door of the great bodhisattva canon, they will serve the Dharma teacher even more respectfully and increase their offerings, up to offering even a water container.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when practicing the perfection of morality, give rise to this thought:

'For a long time I have been far from good friends, constrained by evil friends, lazy and indolent, with inferior diligence, ignorant and foolish. Due to this, with wrong views, such belief and acceptance, such desires and pleasures, I falsely give rise to this thought, denying the karmic retribution for such wholesome actions as welcoming, bowing, kneeling, paying homage with palms joined, and inquiring after one's well-being. Conceited and arrogant, I have created much evil karma.
Due to the retribution of evil karma, they are reborn in the human realm with a contemptible and defiled form, and have never cultivated pure wisdom and life in the fields of merit.
